Content.Title: String Declaration
Content.Description: In the script editor, declare a variable named myName and assign it to your own name. Afterwards, run your code with the Test Code button below. If you're unsure, press the Reveal Hint button. Make sure you have opened the Output window, so you can see errors.
Content.Hint: You can write text with a string, which is wrapped in "quotation marks".
Content.Validator: return typeof(myName) == 'string'

Content.Title: Number Declaration
Content.Description: Declare a variable named myNumber and assign it to a number. The number must use a decimal, meaning it cannot be a whole number.
Content.Hint: Numbers are not wrapped in quotation marks, as they are not strings.
Content.Validator: return typeof(myNumber) == 'number' and myNumber % 1 ~= 0

Content.Title: Boolean Declaration
Content.Description: Declare a variable named <font color="rgb(85,170,255)">myBoolean</font> and assign it to any Boolean value.
Content.Hint: Booleans are either true or false, and must not be wrapped in quotation marks.
Content.Validator: return typeof(myBoolean) == 'boolean'

Content.Title: Outputting Variables
Content.Description: Declare a variable with any name and assign it to a string. Then, use the print function to output the variable's value.
Content.Hint: After assigning your variable, you can call the print function by typing print, followed by round brackets containing the variable's name.
Content.Validator: wait() local log = game:GetService('LogService'):GetLogHistory() log = log[#log].message for var, value in getfenv() do if typeof(value) == 'string' and typeof(log) == 'string' then if log:find(value) then return true end end end return false
Content.ScriptValidator: local c = (userCode:gsub('%s', '')) return c:find('=') ~= nil and c:find('print%(') ~= nil and c:find('print%("') == nil and c:find("print%('") == nil and c:find('print%[%[') == nil

Content.Title: Basic Addition
Content.Description: It's Josh's birthday tomorrow! ðŸ¥³ Declare a variable named joshAge and assign it to 19. Next, use the print function to output his age tomorrow.
Content.Hint: Josh will be 20 years old tomorrow. You can use the addition operator to add two numbers together.
Content.Validator: if typeof(joshAge) ~= 'number' then return false end wait() local log = game:GetService('LogService'):GetLogHistory() if log[#log].message:find('20') then return true end return false
Content.ScriptValidator: return userCode:find('19') ~= nil and userCode:find('+') ~= nil

Content.Title: Order of Operations
Content.Description: Come up with any expression, as complex as you would like, that outputs 100. Examples: print(10 ^ 2) print(9 * 9 + 9 * 2 + 1) print((30 - 5) * 2 + 50) Bonus points if you use variables, order of operations and brackets!
Content.Hint: You can complete this challenge however you like, it is simply designed to let you experiment. Even <font face="Code">print(100)</font> will work!
Content.Validator: wait() local log = game:GetService('LogService'):GetLogHistory() if log[#log].message:find('100') then return true end return false

Questions.Question: Which of these is not a valid data type in Luau?
Which of these variable names is written in camel case?
Which operator concatenates two strings?
What happens if you declare a variable after outputting it?
Questions.False2: The output window shows the variable's value

Categories.Title: Episode 2
Categories.Subtitle: If Statements
Categories.Template:
-- Before completing this exercise, please watch the episode below.
-- Have feedback? Feel free to send me a tweet @ twitter.com/jotslo
-- EPISODE 2: https://youtube.com/watch?v=abcdefghij

Content.Title: Basic Comparison
Content.Description: Declare a variable named myBoolean, and assign to any Boolean value by comparing two values. Finally, output the contents of the variable. Your script must not contain keywords true or false.
Content.Hint: You can compare two values with the equality operator (==), or any other operators mentioned in the tutorial.
Content.Validator: wait() local log = game:GetService('LogService'):GetLogHistory() if log[#log].message:find('true') or log[#log].message:find('false') then return typeof(myBoolean) == 'boolean' end return false
Content.ScriptValidator: return userCode:find('true') == nil and userCode:find('false') == nil

Content.Title: If Statement
Content.Description: Create an if statement that checks if 10 is greater than or equal to 5. If it is, output the string 'Success'
Content.Hint: The greater than or equal to operator (>=) is used to check if one value is greater than or equal to another.
Content.Validator: wait() local log = game:GetService('LogService'):GetLogHistory() if log[#log].message:lower():find('success') then return true end return false
Content.ScriptValidator: return userCode:find('>=') ~= nil and userCode:find('10') ~= nil and userCode:find('5') ~= nil

Content.Title: Else Block
Content.Description: Create an if statement that checks if 8 is less than 3. If it is, output the string 'Success' Otherwise, output the string 'Failure'
Content.Hint: You should use an else block, which is an extension to the if statement. The else block runs when no conditions in the if statement are met.
Content.Validator: wait() local log = game:GetService('LogService'):GetLogHistory() if log[#log].message:lower():find('failure') then return true end return false
Content.ScriptValidator: return userCode:find('<') ~= nil and userCode:find('8') ~= nil and userCode:find('3') ~= nil and userCode:find('else') ~= nil

Content.Title: Elseif Block
Content.Description: Create an if statement with at least one elseif block, and one else block. Feel free to try this challenge multiple times, to try out different formats. Remember blocks underneath the first block with a truthy condition will be ignored.
Content.Hint: If any blocks within an if statement are truthy, the computer runs the code within its block and ignores the remaining blocks. Feel free to rewatch the tutorial if unsure.
Content.Validator: return true
Content.ScriptValidator: return userCode:find('if') ~= nil and userCode:find('else%s') ~= nil and userCode:find('elseif') ~= nil

Content.Title: Local Variables
Content.Description: Create an if statement that executes, and declare a local variable named myVar inside of its scope. The variable should be assigned to the number 13 In the if statement's scope, output the variable's value. Outside the if statement's scope after running, output the variable's value again, where it should not have a value.
Content.Hint: Local variables can only be accessed inside of a scope. If you declare a variable inside the if statement, it will not have a value outside of it, and so should output nil.
Content.Validator: wait() local log = game:GetService('LogService'):GetLogHistory() if myVar then return false end if log[#log-1].message:lower():find('13') and log[#log].message:lower():find('nil') then return true end return false
Content.ScriptValidator: return userCode:find('myVar') and not userCode:find('print(\'') and not userCode:find('print("')

Questions.Question: Which of these represents less than or equal to?
What does the local keyword do?
Questions.Answer: Makes a variable local to a specific scope
Questions.False1: Makes a variable accessible from a LocalScript
Questions.False2: Stops a variable from being accessed in other scripts

Questions.Question:
What does this condition return?
<font face="Code">(3 == 3 or 4 < 3) and true</font>
When does the code within an else block run?
Questions.Answer: When all other blocks in the if statement are falsy
Questions.False1: After running the first code block in the if statement
Questions.False3: After running the code within an elseif block

Questions.Question: Why do we use tabs/spaces to indent code?
Questions.Answer: It makes the code easier to read
Questions.False2: Indentation makes the script run faster

Categories.Subtitle: Loops
Categories.Template:
-- Before completing this exercise, please watch the episode below.
-- Have feedback? Feel free to send me a tweet @ twitter.com/jotslo

Content.Title: For Loop #1
Content.Description: Using a for loop, write a script that outputs each value from 1 to 100. You may only use the print keyword once in your script.
Content.Hint: You can create a for loop ranging from 1 to 100. On each loop, the variable is incremented by the step value, which defaults to 1.
Content.Validator: wait() local log = game:GetService('LogService'):GetLogHistory() for i = 0, 99 do if not log[#log-i].message:find(100 - i) then return false end end return true
Content.ScriptValidator: local _, count = userCode:gsub('print', '') return userCode:find('for') ~= nil and count == 1

Content.Title: For Loop #2
Content.Description: Using a for loop, write a script that outputs each value from 20 to -20, with a step of -2. You may only use the print keyword once in your script.
Content.Hint: You can create a for loop ranging from 20 to -20, with a third value representing the step of -2. On each loop, the variable is incremented by the step value, so the output should look like 20, 18, 16 ... -16, -18, -20
Content.Validator: wait() local log = game:GetService('LogService'):GetLogHistory() for i = 0, 20 do if not log[#log-i].message:find(-20 + i * 2) then return false end end return true
Content.ScriptValidator: local _, count = userCode:gsub('print', '') return userCode:find('for') ~= nil and count == 1

Content.Title: While Loop
Content.Description: Using a variable and a while loop, write a script that outputs each value from 1 to 100. You may only use the print keyword once in your script. Warning: Make sure your while loop doesn't run for an infinite amount of time, or Roblox Studio will hang.
Content.Hint: An example of this challenge is given in the tutorial, incrementing a variable from 1 to 5. You should increment your variable until it reaches 100.
Content.Validator: wait() local log = game:GetService('LogService'):GetLogHistory() for i = 0, 99 do if not log[#log-i].message:find(100 - i) then return false end end return true
Content.ScriptValidator: local _, count = userCode:gsub('print', '') return userCode:find('while') ~= nil and count == 1

Content.Title: Repeat Loop
Content.Description: Using a variable and a repeat loop, write a script that outputs each value from 0 to 50. You may only use the print keyword once in your script. Warning: Make sure your repeat loop doesn't run for an infinite amount of time, or Roblox Studio will hang.
Content.Hint: An example of this challenge is given in the tutorial, incrementing a variable from 1 to 5. You should assign your variable to 0, and increment it until it reaches 50.
Content.Validator: wait() local log = game:GetService('LogService'):GetLogHistory() for i = 0, 50 do if not log[#log-i].message:find(50 - i) then return false end end return true
Content.ScriptValidator: local _, count = userCode:gsub('print', '') return userCode:find('repeat') ~= nil and count == 1

Content.Title: Continue Keyword
Content.Description: Using any loop, output each value from 1 to 10, but skip the number 5. You may only use the print keyword once in your script.
Content.Hint: You should use an if statement that checks the current value, and the continue keyword, which allows you to skip the current iteration of the loop. You can use the continue keyword inside any loop.
Content.Validator: wait() local log = game:GetService('LogService'):GetLogHistory() for i = 0, 4 do if not log[#log-i].message:find(10 - i) then return false end end for i = 6, 9 do if not log[#log-(i-1)].message:find(10 - i) then return false end end return true
Content.ScriptValidator: local _, count = userCode:gsub('print', '') return userCode:find('continue') ~= nil and count == 1

Content.Title: Break Keyword
Content.Description: Write a for loop that outputs each value from 1 to 10, but stop the for loop after the script has outputted 5. You may only use the print keyword once in your script.
Content.Hint: You should use an if statement that checks the current value, and the break keyword, which allows you to break the loop and skip to the code underneath the block. You can use the break keyword inside any loop.
Content.Validator: wait() local log = game:GetService('LogService'):GetLogHistory() for i = 0, 4 do if not log[#log-i].message:find(5 - i) then return false end end return true
Content.ScriptValidator: local _, count = userCode:gsub('print', '') return userCode:find('break') ~= nil and userCode:find('10') ~= nil and count == 1

Content.Title: Do Block
Content.Description: Declare a local variable named myNum inside a do block. The variable should be assigned to the number 26 In the do block's scope, output the variable's value. Outside the do blocks scope after running, output the variable's value again, where it should not have a value.
Content.Hint: Local variables can only be accessed inside of a scope. If you declare a variable inside the do block, it will not have a value outside of it, and so should output nil.
Content.Validator: wait() local log = game:GetService('LogService'):GetLogHistory() if myNum then return false end if log[#log-1].message:lower():find('26') and log[#log].message:lower():find('nil') then return true end return false
Content.ScriptValidator: return userCode:find('myNum') and not userCode:find('print(\'') and not userCode:find('print("')

Questions.Question:
What does this script do?
<font face="Code">while 2 > 1 do print('hello!') end</font>
Questions.Answer: Create an infinite loop, causing Roblox to hang

Questions.Question: Why is a do block useful?
Questions.Answer: It creates a new scope for local variables
Questions.False1: It runs code in a loop
Questions.False2: It allows you to access variables in other scripts

Questions.Question: What does the third value given to the for loop represent?
Why would you use a repeat loop over a while loop?
Questions.Answer: It runs the code block once, before checking the condition
Questions.False1: You can't create an infinite loop
Questions.False3: While loops don't run the code block multiple times

Questions.Question: How do you exit a loop before finishing it?
How do you skip the remaining code block and go to the next iteration?

Categories.Subtitle: Tables
Categories.Template:
-- Before completing this exercise, please watch the episode below.

Content.Title: Empty Table
Content.Description: Declare a variable named myTable and assign it to an empty table.
Content.Hint: Tables are created with curly brackets.
Content.Validator: return typeof(myTable) == 'table' and next(myTable) == nil

Content.Title: List-style Table
Content.Description: Declare a variable named myTable and assign it to a table. The table should be formatted as a list, meaning you must not specify the indexes. Insert the following values to the table, in this order: 's', 7, true, false
Content.Hint: Tables can be created in a list-style format, where the indexes are not specified. This is done within the curly brackets.
Content.Validator: return typeof(myTable) == 'table' and myTable[1] == 's' and myTable[2] == 7 and myTable[3] == true and myTable[4] == false

Content.Title: List-style Table #2
Content.Description: Declare a variable named myTable and assign it to a table. The table should be formatted as a list, meaning you must not specify the indexes. Insert any values into the table. Afterwards, output the length of the table.
Content.Hint: The # operator can determine the length of a table.
Content.Validator: wait() if not typeof(myTable) == 'table' then return false end local log = game:GetService('LogService'):GetLogHistory() if log[#log].message:lower():find(#myTable) then return true end return false

Content.Title: Dictionary-style Table
Content.Description: Declare a variable named ages and assign it to a table. The table must store the ages of the following people: 'John' is 27, 'Jane' is 25, 'Bob' is 32. The names (strings) must be used as the indexes, and the ages (numbers) as the values. After declaring the table, output the age of 'John', by referring to the table.
Content.Hint: The table should be formatted like: {['Adam'] = 25, ...}. Afterwards, you must refer to the table and use the index to retrieve the value.
Content.Validator: wait() if not typeof(ages) == 'table' then return false end local log = game:GetService('LogService'):GetLogHistory() if log[#log].message:lower():find('27') and ages['John'] == 27 and ages['Jane'] == 25 and ages['Bob'] == 32 then return true end return false
Content.ScriptValidator: return not userCode:find('print(\'') and not userCode:find('print("') and not userCode:find('print(27')

Content.Title: Generic For Loop
Content.Description: Declare a variable named myTable and assign it to a table. The table should be formatted as a list, meaning you must not specify the indexes. Insert any values into the table. The table must contain at least 2 values. Afterwards, use a for loop to output each value in the table in order. You may only use the print keyword once in your script.
Content.Hint: You should use the generic for loop, which is mentioned in the video. For each value, simply output the variable referring to the value.
Content.Validator: wait() if (not typeof(myTable) == 'table') or #myTable < 2 then return false end local log = game:GetService('LogService'):GetLogHistory() for i = 0, #myTable - 1 do if not log[#log-i].message:find(myTable[#myTable-i]) then return false end end return true
Content.ScriptValidator: local _, count = userCode:gsub('print', '') return count == 1 and not userCode:find('print(\'') and not userCode:find('print("')

Content.Title: Generic For Loop #2
Content.Description: Declare a variable named myTable and assign it to a table. The table should be formatted as a dictionary, meaning you must specify the indexes. Insert any indexes and values into the table. The table must contain at least 2 sets of indexes & values. Afterwards, use a for loop to get each index and value in the table. On each loop, concatenate the index and value into a string, and output the string. You may only use the print keyword once in your script.
Content.Hint: You should use the generic for loop. For each value, concatenate both the index and the value using the '..' operator, and output the string.
Content.Validator: wait() if (not typeof(myTable) == 'table') then return false end local log = game:GetService('LogService'):GetLogHistory() local len = 0 for i, v in myTable do len += 1 end local function find(msg) for i, v in myTable do if msg:find(tostring(i)) and msg:find(tostring(v)) then return true end end return false end for i = 0, len - 1 do if not find(log[#log-i].message) then return false end end return true
Content.ScriptValidator: local _, count = userCode:gsub('print', '') return count == 1 and not userCode:find('print(\'') and not userCode:find('print("')

Questions.Question: Why are tables useful?
Questions.Answer: They can store lots of information in a single variable
Questions.False2: Tables prevent the script from erroring
Questions.False3: Tables are required in every script

Questions.Question: When can you refer to a table with a dot, rather than square brackets?
Questions.Answer: When the index is a string
Questions.False1: When the index is a number
Questions.False2: When the index is a Boolean
Questions.False3: When the index is a function

Questions.Question: What is the limit of values that can be stored in a table?

What is the index of '3' in this table?
<font face="Code">{2, 3, 7, 1}</font>

How would you refer to 'x' in this table?
<font face="Code">t = {2, {1, 'x'}}</font>

Content.Title: Basic Function
Content.Description: Declare a function named myFunction, that outputs the number 15 when called. Afterwards, call the function.
Content.Hint: You don't need to pass any arguments to the function, simply have it output the number 15.
Content.Validator: if not typeof(myFunction) == 'function' then return false end wait() local log = game:GetService('LogService'):GetLogHistory() if log[#log].message:lower():find('15') then return true end return false

Content.Title: Returning Values
Content.Description: Declare a function named getName, that returns your name when called. You do not need to call the function.
Content.Hint: Use the 'return' keyword to return any string value.
Content.Validator: return typeof(getName) == 'function' and typeof(getName()) == 'string'

Content.Title: Arguments
Content.Description: Declare a function named multiply, that takes two numbers as arguments. You can name your parameters anything you think is suitable. Your function must then multiply the two value, and return the result. Feel free to call the function with any two numbers to test it.
Content.Hint: You can create two parameters between the brackets which are your variables, and then use the '*' operator to multiply them.
Content.Validator: return typeof(multiply) == 'function' and multiply(5, 6) == 30

Content.Title: Basic Logic
Content.Description: Declare a function named isLarge, that takes one number as an argument. You can name your parameter anything you think is suitable. Your function must return true if the number is greater than OR equal to 100, and false if it is less than 100. You do not need to call the function.
Content.Hint: You can either use an if statement, or use a condition to determine if the number is greater than or equal to 100. Refer to episode 2 for more information.
Content.Validator: return typeof(isLarge) == 'function' and isLarge(100) == true and isLarge(99) == false and isLarge(3434) == true and isLarge(-1) == false

Content.Title: Multple Returned Values
Content.Description: Declare a function named getNumbers, that returns the numbers 10 and 20 You must return the values separately, meaning you must not return a table. You shouldn't create any parameters for your function. Afterwards, declare two variables, num1 and num2, call the function, and assign them the values returned by the function.
Content.Hint: You can return multiple pieces of data by separating the values with a comma. When calling the function, you can assign the returned values to variables, separated by a comma.
Content.Validator: if typeof(getNumbers) ~= 'function' then return false end a, b = getNumbers() return typeof(num1) == 'number' and typeof(num2) == 'number' and num1 == 10 and num2 == 20 and a == 10 and b == 20

Content.Title: Libraries
Content.Description: Declare a table named myLib, that contains a function named add. The function should take two numbers as arguments, add them together and return the result. Finally, call the function passing values 6 and 7 as arguments, and then output the result.
Content.Hint: You can add a function as a value to a table just like any other data type. You can then call the function by using the table name and the function name, separated by a period. The expected output is 13.
Content.Validator: wait() if not (typeof(myLib) == 'table' and typeof(myLib.add) == 'function') then return false end local log = game:GetService('LogService'):GetLogHistory() if log[#log].message:lower():find('13') and myLib.add(1,2) == 3 then return true end return false

Questions.Question: Which of these happens when you use the 'return' keyword?
Questions.Answer: The function stops, similar to the break keyword
Questions.False2: The function runs again, like a loop

Questions.Question:
Why are functions generally declared like this?
<font face="Code">function myFunc()</font>
Questions.False3: Functions can only be declared like this

Questions.Question: What is returned by a function if you don't return anything?
What happens if you try to call the same function twice?
Questions.False1: It will ignore the second call

Questions.Question:
How would you call the function in this table?
<font face="Code">f = {function() print('Hello!') end}</font>

Categories.Title: Episode 6
Categories.Subtitle: Instances
Categories.Template:
-- Before completing this exercise, please watch the episode below.

Content.Title: Properties
Content.Description: Manually add a new Part to the Workspace, and name it MyPart. In the script editor, write a script that changes the part's name to NamedPart.
Content.Hint: You can reference the part by navigating to game.Workspace.MyPart. Re-assign the .Name property just as you would an index in a table.
Content.Validator: return workspace:FindFirstChild('NamedPart')

Content.Title: Properties #2
Content.Description: In the script editor, refer to the Baseplate part in the Workspace. Next, change its Transparency property to 0.5.
Content.Hint: The Baseplate is just a Part, so you can reference it the same way as a standard part. You can also change the transparency of the part by setting the .Transparency property.
Content.Validator: return workspace:FindFirstChild('Baseplate').Transparency == 0.5

Content.Title: Methods
Content.Description: In the script editor, refer to the NamedPart in the Workspace. Next, call the Destroy method, to destroy the part.
Content.Hint: After referring to the part, use the :Destroy() method to destroy it. Refer to the tutorial if you're unsure.
Content.Validator: return not workspace:FindFirstChild('NamedPart')

Content.Title: Methods #2
Content.Description: Use the GetChildren()method to get a table containing each child in the Workspace. Next, iterate through the table, and output the Name of each child.
Content.Hint: The GetChildren() method returns a table of all the children in an instance. You can iterate through the table using a for loop, and output the child's name using the .Name property of each value in the table.
Content.Validator: wait() local log = game:GetService('LogService'):GetLogHistory() local len = 0 for i, v in workspace:GetChildren() do len += 1 end local function find(msg) for i, v in workspace:GetChildren() do if msg:find(v.Name) then return true end end return false end for i = 0, len - 1 do if not find(log[#log-i].message) then return false end end return true

Content.Title: Events
Content.Description: All instances have an event called ChildAdded, which fires when a child is added to the instance. When the event is fired, one argument is passed, which refers to the new instance that has been added. In the script editor, refer to the Workspace instance and listen for the ChildAdded event. Next, output the Name of the child that was added. When you click the 'Test Code' button, a new part will be automatically added to the Workspace. You will pass this challenge if your script outputs the name of the new part.
Content.Hint: Refer to the Engine API for an example of ChildAdded being used. Your parameter can be named anything, and you must them use the .Name property to get the name of the child.
Content.Validator: local name = 'NewPart' .. tostring(math.random(1000, 9999)) local part = Instance.new('Part') part.Name = name part.Parent = workspace wait() local log = game:GetService('LogService'):GetLogHistory() if log[#log-i].message:find(name) then return true end return false

Questions.Question: Which of these does NOT reference a part's 'Name' property?
What does the 'game' keyword refer to?
Why do we use a colon when calling a method?
Questions.Answer: It automatically passes the instance as the first argument
Questions.False1: It is much faster than using a dot
Questions.False2: You can't use a dot when calling a method
Questions.False3: Methods are always called with a colon

Questions.Question: What happens if an event is fired mulitple times
Questions.Answer: The callback function is called each time
Questions.False1: The function will only get called the first time

Questions.Question:
According to the Engine API, what would this method return?
<font face="Code">game.Workspace.MyPart:GetFullName()</font>
